title: {{< iconify twemoji flag-turkey >}} Turkish Local Elections 2024
text:
Methodology
In collaboration with Who Targets Me, we monitored 6686 political advertisers to better understand how campaigns use different targeting methods made available by Meta. To do this, we used data from the Meta Ad Library, using the new ‚ÄòAudience‚Äô data which gives some detail on how pages target their ads.






Note



Meta only provides 7, 30 and 90 days windows for the targeting data in their Ad Library. Meta‚Äôs data also lags by a few days. Report will be updated as soon as new data is available.








Disclaimer



The data shown in this dashboard is based on the platform‚Äôs respective ad libraries which are known to be sometimes incomplete (Edelson et al.¬†2020; Silva et al.¬†2020). For this reason the data shown here might not reflect the full picture nor all political ads that were targeted at voters.




About the Creators of the Dashboard

Onurcan G√ºdenFabio Votta













Onurcan G√ºden is a PhD candidate in Media and Communication Studies at the Galatasaray University and a visiting researcher at the University of Amsterdam. His research focuses on the impact of computational propaganda in shaping digital political agendas in different democracies and its societal consequences.



















Fabio Votta is a Postdoc at the University of Amsterdam who studies (online) political microtargeting and its usage around the world.














Want to see how political parties target you? Sign up at Who Targets Me and download the gratis browser plugin to see how parties on Facebook use your data:
https://whotargets.me/







Want to retrieve targeting data from the Facebook Ad Library yourself? This dashboard is powered by the R package: metatargetr. Check it out here:
https://github.com/favstats/metatargetr




Election Targeting Dashboards
A list of election dashboards:

üá≥üá± 2021 Dutch parliamentary election (15th-17th March 2021)
üá©üá™ 2021 German federal election (26 September 2021)
üá∏üá™ 2022 Swedish general election (11th September 2022)
üá∫üá∏ 2022 United States midterm elections (8th November 2022)
üá∫üá∏ 2022 United States midterm elections - Georgia Runoff (6th December 2022)
üáÆüáπ 2023 Lazio & Lombardy regional election (12-13th February 2023)
üá™üá™ 2023 Estonian parliamentary election (5th March 2023)
üá≥üá± 2023 Dutch provincial elections (15th March 2023)
üá≤üá™ 2023 Montenegrin presidential elections (19th March 2023) - 1st round
üá¶üá∫ 2023 New South Wales state election (25th March 2023)
üá´üáÆ 2023 Finnish parliamentary election (2 April 2023)
üáπüá∑ 2023 Turkish general election (14 May 2023) - Round 1
üá©üá™ 2023 Bremen State election (14 May 2023)
üá¨üá∑ 2023 Greek Legislative election (21 May 2023)
üáπüá∑ 2023 Turkish Presidential election (14 May 2023) - Round 2
üá≤üá™ 2023 Montenegrin parliamentary elections (11 June 2023)
üá¨üá∑ 2nd 2023 Greek Legislative election (25 May 2023)
üá∏üá∞ 2023 Slovak parliamentary election (30 September 2023)
üá©üá™ 2023 Bavarian state election (8 October 2023)
üá©üá™ 2023 Hessian state election (8 October 2023)
üá≥üáø 2023 New Zealand general election (14 October 2023)
üáµüá± 2023 Polish parliamentary election (15 October 2023)

Methodology
In collaboration with Who Targets Me, we monitored 279 political advertisers to better understand how campaigns use different targeting methods made available by Meta. To do this, we used data from the Meta Ad Library, using the new ‚ÄòAudience‚Äô data which gives some detail on how pages target their ads.






Note



Meta only provides 7, 30 and 90 days windows for the targeting data in their Ad Library. Meta‚Äôs data also lags by a few days. Report will be updated as soon as new data is available.








Disclaimer



The data shown in this dashboard is based on the platform‚Äôs respective ad libraries which are known to be sometimes incomplete (Edelson et al.¬†2020; Silva et al.¬†2020). For this reason the data shown here might not reflect the full picture nor all political ads that were targeted at voters.




About the Creators of the Dashboard

Onurcan G√ºdenFabio Votta













Onurcan G√ºden is a PhD candidate in Media and Communication Studies at the Galatasaray University and a visiting researcher at the University of Amsterdam. His research focuses on the impact of computational propaganda in shaping digital political agendas in different democracies and its societal consequences.



















Fabio Votta is a Postdoc at the University of Amsterdam who studies (online) political microtargeting and its usage around the world.














Want to see how political parties target you? Sign up at Who Targets Me and download the gratis browser plugin to see how parties on Facebook use your data:
https://whotargets.me/







Want to retrieve targeting data from the Facebook Ad Library yourself? This dashboard is powered by the R package: metatargetr. Check it out here:
https://github.com/favstats/metatargetr

title: {{< iconify twemoji flag-turkey >}} Turkish Local Elections 2024
text: Show all data

title: Analyzing the Landscape of Local Elections in T√ºrkiye: A Deep Dive into Micro-Targeted Advertising on Meta
text:
As we near the two-week countdown to the local elections in T√ºrkiye, the main opposition party, the CHP, has taken the lead in spending on micro-targeted ads across Meta platforms in the country. This represents a significant shift from last year‚Äôs presidential and parliamentary elections, during which the CHP lagged far behind the ruling AKP in Meta ad spend.
On the other hand, we observe that the AKP is channeling substantial funds into advertising in major cities such as Istanbul, ƒ∞zmir, Bursa, Antalya, Adana, Ordu, and Hatay. This demonstrates a strategic emphasis on the AKP‚Äôs desire to take over municipalities it does not have. In contrast, the CHP outspends AKP in Ankara, Manisa, Aydƒ±n, Denizli, and Malatya, indicating a nuanced approach to capturing different regional demographics.




In Istanbul, where 11,314,516 individuals are set to cast their votes, the AKP candidate, Murat Kurum (on the right), outspends his rival from the CHP, Ekrem ƒ∞mamoƒülu (on the left), by 3.2 times.



Elections become further complicated by the involvement of unofficial accounts, which play a pivotal role in shaping how voters perceive the candidates and issues. Pages like ‚Äúƒ∞stanbul Ger√ßekleri‚Äù specifically target Ekrem ƒ∞mamoƒülu, a prominent figure for the CHP in ƒ∞stanbul, with direct attack ads. Similarly, ‚ÄúAntalya Ger√ßekleri‚Äù in Antalya and ‚ÄúYeni Mikrofon‚Äù in Ankara are actively engaged in negative campaigning against CHP candidates. On the flip side, ‚ÄúUnutma ƒ∞stanbul‚Äù page seeks to sway voters by recalling the period when Istanbul was under AKP management.




The ad on the ‚Äúƒ∞stanbul Ger√ßekleri‚Äù page claims that Ekrem ƒ∞mamoƒülu has been using municipal funds for his own public relations purposes.



Examining the targeting dimensions of Meta ads reveals a strategy finely tuned to specific groups. The AKP‚Äôs focus on parents with children in nursery and elementary schools, alongside the CHP is targeting users with a keen interest in Ottoman history, nationalist music, the ‚ÄúDirili≈ü Ertuƒürul‚Äù series, and theology students and graduates.
As the local elections approach, the landscape of political advertising on Meta platforms provides a glimpse into the evolving tactics of voter persuasion in T√ºrkiye. The emergence of unofficial accounts and micro-targeted ads highlights the increasingly nuanced battle for hearts and minds in the digital arena.

title: Welcome to the 2024 Turkish Local Elections Dashboard
text:
Keep track on how political parties and other unlabelled actors use digital advertising on Meta and what audiences they are trying to reach.



Welcome to the 2024 Turkish Local Elections Dashboard. This dashboard is intended to provide an overview of how political parties and various actors are leveraging digital advertising on Meta platforms, targeting specific audiences. Our goal is to create transparency for citizens, journalists, and other interested parties, and helping you understand the strategies behind these digital campaigns as we approach the local elections.
Digital advertising is a powerful tool in modern political campaigns, and this dashboard opens up a window into common strategies. Whether you‚Äôre interested in the tactics used by different parties or how they‚Äôre trying to reach potential voters, feel free to explore the data on this dashboard. Stay informed with us as we explore the role of digital advertising in the 2024 Turkish Local Elections.

title: Spending per Targeting
text:
Data for: All
These charts show the groups that political parties target with their advertisements leading up to the elections, according to the latest data. The focus is on Meta‚Äôs platforms (Facebook and Instagram) because they offer the most detailed targeting options for political advertisements.
How much did the campaigns of political parties spend on different audiences? The charts below show both the total and the expenditures per party.

Note: Different targeting criteria may overlap, so the outcome may not necessarily add up to 100%.
